1150721715116367872.text: Sanctions waivers that legitimize “civil nuclear cooperation” with Iran are legacies of the failed JCPOA strategic framework.  It’s time to take another step in restoring the pre-JCPOA consensus by ending these waivers, which legitimize Iran’s illicit nuclear program.

1102984081543962624.text: Loans put big purchases within reach for middle-class Americans, whether they’re buying a dishwasher or a house. But PACE loans are different—they’re making life less affordable for many Americans. @CFPB’s new rules must stop that. END/

1102984080424079361.text: PACE loans also get priority over others debts, w/ the taxman serving as debt collector. The PACE lender gets its taste before federal finance agencies or anyone else. No other loan can do this.

1102984079434231808.text: PACE loans are odd b/c the lender doesn’t have to confirm you make enough money to afford the loan. They just check the value of your home. Can’t come up w/ the money later? That’s OK. You’ll lose your home & the PACE lender will take its cut from the sale price.

1102984078394052614.text: PACE loans are paid through your property taxes. And they typically have higher interest rates than normal home loans. So some Americans get blindsided months later by tax bills they can’t afford.

1102984077358047232.text: Here’s how it works: A PACE lender comes to your door & says you can lower your electricity bill right now by signing on the dotted line. But wait, there’s more…

1102984076154294272.text:
PACE loans are unlike any other type of loan on the market. Financiers are essentially tricking people—especially seniors—into unaffordable, decades-long loans to pay for solar panels.
https://t.co/8nGTiXbKvr

1075117658071334912.text:
The First Step Act provides hundreds of new rights and privileges to federal prisoners. More phone time, reduced sentences, “compassionate release,” and early release credits.
 
There is not a single benefit in the bill for the victims of these criminals.

1075117654707441668.text: Opponents falsely claim victim notification amendment wouldn’t allow victims to opt-out of notification. Current law for other notifications doesn’t mention “opt-outs,” but Bureau of Prisons still provides it. This will not change.

1075117651217780736.text:
The amendment I offered with @SenJohnkennedy, cosponsored by Senators Barrasso, Kyl, Sasse, and Toomey, would notify victims before their victimizer is granted early prerelease custody and give victims a chance to make a statement to the warden. 
 
I hope my colleagues vote yes.

1075056463964504065.text:
I am proud to have support from the Major City Chiefs of Police for our amendments. These brave Chiefs serve nearly 80 million Americans and they are heroes who keep us safe.
 
Criminals get a lot of benefits in First Step Act. Why not at least give victims notice? https://t.co/7hlFmCRRhB

1075054123198922759.text: The senate should unanimously pass @SenatorLankford amendment #4121 to fix language in current bill that discriminates against Christian and other religious groups. Proud to sponsor this fix. Faith-based groups deserve full participation in federal prison system.

1075035232393461760.text: I'm proud to have @SenJohnKennedy, @SenJohnBarrasso, Senator Kyl, @SenSasse, and @SenToomey as cosponsors for this amendment. We only need 51 votes to make this bill a little better and safer. I urge all my colleagues to support it.

1075035230996742144.text: Now, please tell me which of the crimes in my amendment should remain eligible for early release time credits. Coercing a child to engage in sexual activity? Assaulting law enforcement? Assaulting a child? Carjacking? Bank robbery? Hate crimes? They should all be made ineligible.

1075035224218705927.text: Opponents of my amendment continue to push false claim it “would make virtually all federal prisoners ineligible for earned time credits,” so I’m posting analysis from bipartisan US Sentencing Commission confirming 62% of prisoners are still eligible if my amendment‘s adopted: https://t.co/ynwVta0e6E

1074843107856973829.text: I also strongly support @jiminhofe's amendment #4141 that would fix the unconstitutional, unfunded mandate in the First Step Act that could bankrupt local jails. This is a serious issue in the bill that has received little attention thus far.

1074843106871312384.text: And @SenSasse would also get rid of the section that reduces the penalty for repeat fentanyl trafficking in amendment #4142. Fentanyl traffickers deserve no leniency. I strongly support.

1074843105453580288.text: In amendment #4143, @SenSasse would fix the "productive activities" loophole that allows violent felons to gain early release credits by playing softball. Why do bill authors allow “productive activities” to qualify?

1074843103964659712.text: The @SenSasse amendment #4144 deserves support. It bans felons who assault police officers, violent bank robbers, and carjackers from early release. Violent offenders should not be eligible for early release to home confinement or to “supervised release.”

1074843102026874880.text: My colleague @Senorrinhatch has introduced comprehensive mens rea reform in amendment #4137 that I hope will be accepted by my colleagues. Disappointed this was not included in bill.

1074843100571406336.text: And @SenToomey amendment #4120 would provide more funding for victims of violent crimes. This is an outstanding and much-needed amendment that deserves my colleagues’ support.

1074843099141206017.text: I also support @SenToomey amendment #4119 that increases the penalty against violent felons who stalk children.

1074843098277167104.text: I am proud to support @SenToomey First Step Act amendment #4118 that would raise the penalty for felons who murder police officers or first responders by ensuring that capital punishment is an option.

1074830087625805824.text: While I still have concerns with First Step Act, I strongly support and am proud to sponsor @SenatorLankford amendment #4121 to ensure faith-based organizations can work with prisoners to improve lives and reduce recidivism. I urge my colleagues to pass this common sense fix.

1065362977350696967.text: House-passed bill said inmates only get “pre-release custody” for new credits. Senate drafters quietly slipped in “or supervised release.” Major change. Supervised release = check in with parole officer, i.e., “release.”

1065362975366815744.text: Proponents now say new “time credits” are not early release b/c inmates use them for “prerelease custody,” not release. 1065362968404209666.text: Here’s what Congressional Budget Office said about the House-passed version (a far more modest-bill, without sentencing reductions): “[the bill] would result in the release of thousands of people from federal prisons earlier than would occur under current law.” No early release? https://t.co/d3I6nhD7Mg

1065362966642655232.text: .@SenMikeLee: “Nothing in the First Step Act gives inmates early release.” But as I showed yesterday, the bill text – confirmed by DOJ –  is clear that repeat fentanyl traffickers can be released from prison in 1/2 the time under the FIRST STEP Act compared to current law.

1065362965141102592.text: My colleague @SenMikeLee and I have a good-faith, substantive disagreement on wisdom of the First Step Act. By looking at bill text, hopefully we can at least agree on the facts.

1064891197792100352.text: This trafficker went from 20-year sentence to out in about 10 years (or less, if combined with programs already in law) if low-risk and out in 15 years if high-risk. Yet proponents claim there’s “no early release.” Should we not hold a hearing on this bill?

1064891195686617088.text: If the trafficker in “low-risk” category, he can use credits to transfer into "pre-release custody or supervised release." In other words, he's out early. If high-risk, trafficker still gets 25% 841(b) reduction. https://t.co/Z52w29VLZL

1064891193333555200.text: Look at vague definition of "productive activities" that result in early release "time credits." Bureau of Prisons said this could include playing softball, watching movies, or playing cards. https://t.co/hxQZlrKtE2

1064891191416758274.text: Some offenders ineligible for this, but fentanyl traffickers are eligible. Only fentanyl organizers—under 10% of traffickers—are excluded. This was sticking point in negotiations. @NationalSheriff & I wanted all excluded. Drafters said no. https://t.co/z9OsaPmkkz

1064891186584977408.text: Then, bill creates new "time credits" section, and trafficker can get 10 days credit per 30 spent in "evidence-based recidivism reduction programming or productive activities." 15 days if “low-risk.” This = up to 1/3rd of the sentence, or 5 out of 15 years. https://t.co/4gl4KzJbAo

1064891184156413952.text: Next, trafficker is eligible for expanded "good time" credits because bill allows offenders to earn 54 days credit for each year sentenced instead of each year served. This section is applied retroactively, too. https://t.co/RIGN8BSEdH
